questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the layer of semilunar valves?
questions.solution:
• The major histologic components of the heart:
    • Pericardium
    • Myocardium
    • Endocardium
    • The valves
  • The PERICARDIUM:
    • Fibrous (parietal)
    • Serous (visceral, also known as epicardium)
    • It is lined by a single layer of mesothelial cells resting on a basement membrane and forms a cavity or potential space filled with a small amount (~60 cc) of fluid.
  • The MYOCARDIUM:
    • Bundles of cardiac muscle fibers (myocytes) separated by fibrous bands.
    • The muscle fibers form a syncytium with end-to-end junctions, called intercalated discs
    • The nuclei of myocytes are centrally located.
  • The ENDOCARDIUM:
    • Single layer of endothelial cells that are continuous with those of the major blood vessels as well as a basement membrane and delicate supporting connective tissue.
  • The SEMILUNAR (PULMONARY AND AORTIC) VALVES are composed of
    • 3 layers: (choice B, C & D)
      1. Fibrosa (made of dense collagen)
      2. Spongiosa (containing large amounts of proteoglycans, loosely arranged collagen fibers, and scattered fibroblasts)
      3. Ventricularis (identified by its profusion of elastic fibers).
  • The ATRIOVENTRICULAR (MITRAL AND TRICUSPID) VALVES:
    • The annulus (a ring of circumferentially oriented collagen and elastic fibers)
    • Leaflets
    • Chordae tendineae
    • Papillary muscles.
  • The leaflets: three layers:
    • The spongiosa (on the atrial side, rich in proteoglycans)
    • The central fibrosa
    • The ventricularis (on the ventricular side, rich in elastic fibers).

Key Takeaways: Semilunar valves have three layers: Fibrosa (collagen), Spongiosa (proteoglycans), and Ventricularis (elastic fibers). Vasculosa is not a layer of semilunar valves.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of mitral valve stenosis?
questions.solution:
MITRAL VALVE STENOSIS

Gross:

  • Leaflet thickening (± calcification)
  • Commissural fusion
  • Cord thickening and fusion

Microscopic:

  • Fibrosis
  • variable inflammation
  • vessels within valve layers

Remote history of rheumatic fever

  • Nearly all cases of mitral valve stenosis (with or without mitral insufficiency) are acquired and post inflammatory (rheumatic) in nature.
  • Among cases of mitral insufficiency, common causes:
    • Myxomatous (floppy)
    • Mitral valve disease (mitral valve prolapse)
    • Post inflammatory
    • Ischemic complication

Grossly, rheumatic Valves show a characteristic appearance that has been compared to repeated dipping in candle wax. The commissures are partially fused (from the annulus inward), giving a resemblance to a "FISH MOUTH". The cords are also thickened and fused, appearing similar to the whiskers/tendrils of a catfish. The presence of vessels with the valve layers is a finding specific to rheumatic valve disease.

Key Takeaways: Mitral valve stenosis typically involves leaflet thickening, commissural fusion, and cord thickening/fusion. Calcific deposits are not characteristic and are more associated with degenerative changes. Most cases result from rheumatic heart disease, with valves showing "fish mouth" deformity.

questions.text: Which myocarditis listed below has the poorest prognosis?
questions.solution:
MYOCARDITIS:

  • The presence of an inflammatory infiltrate and myocyte necrosis or degeneration (the two components of the so-called dallas criteria)
  • Lymphocytic infiltrate admixed with histiocytes and occasional granulocytes (neutrophils and eosinophils)
  • In hypersensitivity myocarditis, the infiltrate is rich in eosinophils, is predominantly perivascular, and is accompanied by a lesser degree of myocyte injury.
  • The myocyte alterations in myocarditis
    • Frank necrosis
    • Vacuolization
    • Disruption
  • Ongoing or persistent myocarditis: when both the myocyte damage and the inflammation persist
  • Resolving or healing myocarditis: when these changes are substantially reduced, and
  • Resolved or healed myocarditis: when these changes are no longer present
  • The etiology of myocarditis: idiopathic, viral, bacterial (including Whipple disease, Coxiella, and Bartonella), mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic (particularly Chagas disease and toxoplasmosis, the latter often seen in AIDS patients), autoimmune disease (especially rheumatic fever "pancarditis"), drug-induced reaction, radiation, or as an expression of transplant rejection.
  • GIANT CELL MYOCARDITIS: a particularly aggressive form
    • Characterized by more widespread multicentric destruction of the cardiac myocytes.
    • The inflammatory infiltrate includes cytotoxic T cells, eosinophils, and the multinucleated cells
    • Well-formed granulomas are not seen in giant cell myocarditis.

Key Takeaways: Out of all forms of myocarditis, Giant cell myocarditis has the poorest prognosis due to its aggressive nature, with widespread myocyte destruction and inflammatory infiltrates, including cytotoxic T cells and eosinophils. Other forms, like idiopathic, hypersensitivity, and viral myocarditis, generally have better outcomes.

questions.text: Which vasculitis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica?
questions.solution:
GIANT CELL (OR TEMPORAL) ARTERITIS:

  • A disease of temporal, cerebral, and retinal arteries.
  • Aortic and large arterial involvement
  • Large vessel vasculitis syndrome
  • After age 70
  • Pain in the distribution of the temporal artery and localized tenderness.
  • Other extracranial carotid artery branches may be affected as well, leading to jaw claudication, facial pain, and blindness (the most feared complication).
  • The syndrome of polymyalgia rheumatica: (choice A)
    • muscle pain
    • tenderness involving mainly the muscles of the neck, shoulder, and pelvic girdle
    • elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate,
    • Responsive to corticosteroid therapy.
  • Complications related to ascending aortic aneurysm
  • Microscopically:
    • Partial destruction of the wall
    • Lymphohistiocytic inflammatory infiltrate, containing multinucleated giant cells.
    • In elastic arteries (especially the ascending aorta), this inflammation is found surrounding "islands" of acellular collapsed elastic lamellae
    • TRANSMURAL INFLAMMATION is the diagnostic hallmark of vasculitis in temporal artery biopsies.

Key Takeaways: Giant cell arteritis is linked to polymyalgia rheumatica, presenting with muscle pain (neck, shoulders, pelvis), temporal artery tenderness, jaw claudication, and risk of blindness. It responds well to corticosteroids.

questions.text: Based on the H&E-stained image below of an 6 years old child with TSC1 mutation, where was this tumor most likely excised from?
questions.solution:
RHABDOMYOMAS:

  • The most frequent primary tumor of the pediatric heart
  • Most common in first years of life
  • 50% of cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations
  • The other 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tuberous sclerosis complex TSC1 or TSC2 tumor suppressor genes. TSC1 or TSC2 expression is often absent in tuberous sclerosis-associated rhabdomyomas, providing a mechanism for myocyte overgrowth.
  • Rhabdomyomas often regress spontaneously, they may be considered as hamartomas rather than true neoplasms.

MORPHOLOGY

  • Gross: Gray-white myocardial masses that can be small or up to several centimetres in diameter. They are usually multiple and involve the ventricles preferentially, protruding into the lumen.
  • Microscopically
    • Bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes with large collections of glycogen. Routine histologic processing removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane, an appearance referred to as "spider" cells (given in the image)

Key Takeaways: Cardiac rhabdomyomas, common in pediatric patients and linked to TSC1/TSC2 mutations (as in tuberous sclerosis), typically involve the ventricles, often showing "spider" cells on histology.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main function of proteoglycans?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is d) Production of extracellular matrix because proteoglycans are integral components of the extracellular matrix (ECM). They play a crucial role in:

  • Structural Support: By forming hydrated gels, proteoglycans provide resistance to compressive forces in tissues such as cartilage.
  • Matrix Organization: They interact with collagen, elastin, and other ECM components to maintain tissue architecture.
  • Cell-Matrix Interactions: Proteoglycans influence cell adhesion, migration, and signalling by binding to integrins and growth factors.

Their ability to retain water and bind diverse molecules makes them essential for the ECM's physical and biochemical properties.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • Regulation of inflammation (a): While proteoglycans can influence inflammation through interactions with cytokines and chemokines, this is not their primary function. It is more of a secondary role in specific biological contexts.
  • Elaboration of prothrombotic molecules (b): Proteoglycans are not directly responsible for prothrombotic activity. This function is typically carried out by endothelial cells and platelets through the production of molecules like thromboxane and tissue factor.
  • Regulation of cell growth (c): Proteoglycans can modulate cell signaling pathways that influence growth, but their primary role lies in structural support and matrix formation rather than direct regulation of growth.

Key Takeaways: Proteoglycans primarily function in the production of extracellular matrix, providing structural support and aiding in tissue organization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a TRUE statement about Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
KAWASAKI SYNDROME (Mucocutaneous lymph nodes syndrome) (choice D)

  • Arteritis impacts medium and small arteries (choice B)
  • Usually < 4 years old (choice A)
  • Presenting with oral, conjunctival and palmoplantar erythema ("strawberry tongue") with a desquamative rash and cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Often lost infectious
  • Predominantly coronary arteries (choice C) involved à Aneurysms & Myocardial infarction
  • Autoantibodies to endothelial/smooth muscle cells.
  • Treat with IVIG and aspirin

Key Takeaways: Kawasaki disease primarily affects children under 4 years, involves medium and small arteries (not large), and presents with mucocutaneous symptoms, coronary artery complications, and lymphadenopathy. Treatment includes IVIG and aspirin. Kawasaki disease symptoms can be remembered as "CRASH and BURN": Conjunctivitis, Rash, Adenopathy (cervical), Strawberry tongue, Hand/foot erythema and desquamation, and BURN (fever > 5 days).

questions.text: Which vasculitis is characterized by fibrinoid necrosis of muscular arteries?
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa

  • Transmural necrotizing arteritis of medium or small arteries (without glomerulonephritis or vasculitis of arterioles, capillaries, or venules) with mixed inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and thrombosis.
  • Frequently involves renal artery and GI tract
  • Often patchy/segmental
  • Immune complex mediated.
  • ~ 30% have chronic Hepatitis B

The rest of the options do not show fibrinoid necrosis.

Key Takeaways: Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by transmural necrotizing arteritis of medium or small arteries with fibrinoid necrosis and thrombosis, commonly affecting the renal and GI arteries. It is immune complex-mediated, and about 30% of cases are associated with chronic Hepatitis B.

questions.text: Choose the correct sequence of prevalence of primary malignant cardiac sarcomas in adults.
questions.solution:
Sarcomas of the heart are exceptionally rare but are the most frequent type of primary cardiac malignancy.

  • Some highly pleomorphic cardiac tumors defy classification (i.e. pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma).
  • Of those that can be placed into a lineage specific category, ANGIOSARCOMA is the most common. They are typically located in the right atrium
  • The second most common category of sarcoma is that of myosarcoma, either leiomyosarcoma or rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Leiomyosarcomas can have spindle cell, epithelioid, or myxoid features. Some of them contain scattered osteoclast-like multinucleated giant cells, like those more commonly seen in leiomyosarcomas of the uterine corpus.
  • Other types: myxofibrosarcoma, pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcomas, osteosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, liposarcoma, synovial sarcoma, Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET), and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor.
  • All of these tumor types are more common in adults than children
  • Primary heart sarcomas present with intractable Congestive heart failure, arrhythmias, or signs of superior vena cava obstruction.

Key Takeaways: Angiosarcoma is the most common primary malignant cardiac sarcoma, typically located in the right atrium. The second most common is leiomyosarcoma, followed by other rare types like synovial sarcoma and fibrosarcoma. These tumors often present with heart failure, arrhythmias, or superior vena cava obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a mechanism of secondary hypertension?
questions.solution:
The vast majority (90% to 95%) of hypertension is idiopathic, the result of interacting genetic and environmental factors.

Mechanisms of Secondary Hypertension:

  • In renovascular hypertension, RENAL ARTERY STENOSIS (choice A) a decreased glomerular flow and pressure in the afferent arteriole of the glomerulus a induces renin secretion leading to increased blood volume and vascular tone via angiotensin and aldosterone pathways
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism (choice C) is one of the most common causes of secondary hypertension.
  • Single-gene disorders
    • Gene defects affecting enzymes involved in aldosterone metabolism (e.g., aldosterone synthase, 11β-hydroxylase, 17α-hydroxylase) can lead to increased aldosterone secretion with downstream increases in salt and water resorption, plasma volume expansion, and, ultimately, hypertension.
  • Mutations affecting proteins that influence sodium reabsorption. For example, the moderately severe form of salt-sensitive hypertension, called Liddle syndrome (choice B), is caused by mutations in an epithelial Na+ channel protein that increase distal tubular reabsorption of sodium in response to aldosterone.

Key Takeaways:

Key Secondary Causes of Hypertension:

  1. Renal Artery Stenosis
  2. Liddle Syndrome
  3. Primary Hyperaldosteronism
  4. Pheochromocytoma
  5. Cushing's Syndrome
  6. Coarctation of the Aorta
  7. Hyperthyroidism
  8. Obstructive Sleep Apnea
  9. Chronic Kidney Disease
  10. Primary Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Choose the incorrect option from the following causes of tricuspid valve insufficiency?
questions.solution:
• Rheumatic fever primarily affects the mitral and aortic valves, leading to stenosis or insufficiency due to post-inflammatory scarring. It does not typically cause tricuspid valve insufficiency.
  • Tricuspid insufficiency is more commonly associated with conditions affecting the right side of the heart, such as Ebstein anomaly, infective endocarditis, and pulmonary venous hypertension.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

  • A) Ebstein anomaly: A congenital condition that causes displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, leading to tricuspid insufficiency. This is a common cause.
  • B) Infective endocarditis: Infection of the tricuspid valve, often due to intravenous drug use or central venous catheters, can cause tricuspid valve damage and insufficiency.
  • C) Pulmonary venous hypertension: Conditions like left-sided heart failure can lead to increased pressure in the pulmonary circuit, which can in turn cause right-sided heart failure and tricuspid valve insufficiency.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tricuspid valve insufficiency can be caused by congenital conditions like Ebstein anomaly, infections such as infective endocarditis, and conditions leading to pulmonary venous hypertension.
  • Rheumatic fever is not a common cause of tricuspid valve insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common major complication of stent placement?
questions.solution:
Angioplasty with stenting has become a mainstay and first line option for treating coronary artery disease and its complications.

  • Various metal alloys (e.g. cobalt chromium, nickel titanium, stainless steel) are used in their construction.
  • The major complication following stent placement is the formation of thrombus within and/or adjacent to the stent. Patients receive aggressive anti-platelet and anticoagulation therapy for months after stent placement to prevent this.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thrombus formation is the most common major complication of stent placement, as blood clots can form inside or around the stent, leading to potential blockages.
  • To prevent thrombus formation, patients are treated with anti-platelet and anticoagulation therapy for months following stent placement.
  • Other complications like aneurysm, mitral valve stenosis, and myocardial infarction are not typically associated with stent placement itself, making them less common.

questions.text: A 46 years old male with chronic hypertension had come to emergency room with sudden onset of excruciating pain, started from anterior chest and radiated to the back. Autopsy sections from the heart reveals the following gross and microscopic features. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Aortic dissection occurs when blood separates the laminar planes of the media to form a blood-filled channel within the aortic wall.

  • Aortic dissection is generally associated with aortic dilation; it can be disastrous if the dissection then ruptures through the adventitia and haemorrhages into adjacent spaces.
  • Disruption of vessel lumen a blood can enter "false lumen" and dissect between layers or rupture.
  • Frequently caused by trauma, but can be sporadic
  • Common sites:
    • Cervical (carotid/vertebral arteries): often younger adults
    • Coronary arteries
    • Aorta: Often older males with history of hypertension. Also associated with marfan syndrome and bicuspid aortic valve.
  • Stanford Type A: Involves ascending aorta (more common)
  • Stanford Type B: Only descending aorta
  • With sporadic cases, microscopically often see "cystic Medial degeneration" with
    1. Marked loss of elastic lamellae (but seen with elastic stain) &
    2. Deposition of proteoglycans (but seen with colloidal iron stain)

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: There is increased risk of aortic stenosis
There is increased risk of development of cor pulmonale
It is associated with hepatitis B antigen

questions.text: A 37 year-old female presents with decreased vision and numbness in her fingers. Physical exam is notable for hypertension and decreased pulses in the upper extremities. A subclavian biopsy shows marked mononuclear infiltrate in the adventitia with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum. Based on the clinical history and histology, which of the following statements regarding the disease is TRUE?
questions.solution:
The history and histology are classic for TAKAYASU ARTERITIS, which is a large vessel vasculitis which typically involves the aortic arch.

  • Involvement of the aortic root may lead to dilation of the aortic valve with subsequent aortic insufficiency, not aortic stenosis (choice A).
  • Takayasu arteritis has no known associations.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa is associated with hepatitis B antigen (choice C) and antiproteinase 3 (choice D) or c-ANCA is associated with Wegener granulomatosis.
  • Although ocular symptoms are more classically associated with giant cell arteritis, there is considerable overlap between these 2 entities, and Takayasu arteritis also has an increased risk of blindness (choice E).
  • Pulmonary arteries are involved in 50% of the patients and can lead to pulmonary hypertension and subsequent cor pulmonale (choice B).

Key Takeaways:

  • Aortic dissection: Blood separates aortic wall layers, causing severe chest pain radiating to the back.
  • Common in older males with hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and bicuspid aortic valve.
  • Type A affects the ascending aorta; Type B involves the descending aorta.
  • Cystic medial degeneration: loss of elastic fibers and proteoglycan deposits in the aorta.

choices.text: Most common in axilla of the children
Neck lesions are associated in cases of turner syndrome more commonly

questions.text: All of the following are true about cystic hygroma, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
LYMPHANGIOMAS

  • Lymphangiomas are the benign lymphatic counterparts of hemangiomas.

SIMPLE (CAPILLARY) LYMPHANGIOMAS are

  • slightly elevated or sometimes pedunculated lesions up to 1 to 2 cm in diameter
  • predominantly in the head, neck, and axillary subcutaneous tissues.
  • Histologically: lymphangiomas exhibit networks of endothelium-lined spaces that can be distinguished from capillary channels by lymphatic endothelial markers (e.g., VEGFR-3, LYVE-1, and others) or by the absence of erythrocytes.

CAVERNOUS LYMPHANGIOMAS (CYSTIC HYGROMAS)

  • Most common location: the neck or axilla of children (choice A) and more rarely in the retroperitoneum.
  • Cavernous lymphangiomas also known as CYSTIC HYGROMA (choice D)
  • up to 15 cm, filling the axilla or producing gross deformities about the neck
  • cavernous lymphangiomas of the neck are common in Turner syndrome. (Choice B)
  • The lesions are composed of Massively Dilated Lymphatic Spaces Lined By Ecs And Separated By Intervening Connective Tissue Stroma Containing Lymphoid Aggregates.
  • The tumor margins are indistinct and unencapsulated (choice C), making resection difficult.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cystic hygroma (cavernous lymphangioma) is most common in the neck and axilla of children.
  • Associated with Turner syndrome (neck lesions).
  • Unencapsulated lesion with indistinct margins, making resection challenging.
  • Not the same as cavernous hemangioma (which involves blood vessels, not lymphatic vessels).

choices.text: Endemic African kaposi sarcoma occurs in HIV positive individuals
Kaposi sarcoma lesions are infected by HPV8
Classic kaposi sarcoma manifests lesions in proximal lower extremities and spreads distally
Patches, raised plaques and nodule forms in classic kaposi sarcoma

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about Kaposi sarcoma?
questions.solution:
KAPOSI SARCOMA - Intermediate grade (borderline) tumor

  • Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8, also known as Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus).
  • Based on population demographics and risk factors, KS is categorized into four forms:
  • Classic KS:
    • Associated with malignancy or altered immunity
    • Not associated with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.
    • Multiple red-purple skin plaques or nodules, in the distal lower extremities; progressively increase in size, spread proximally (choice c)
    • Asymptomatic, localized to the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Endemic African KS:
    • Typically occurs in HIV-seronegative individuals (choice A)
    • Younger than age 40 years
    • Indolent or aggressive course
    • Involves lymph nodes much more frequently
    • The more common in central Africa
    • Occurs in prepubertal children
    • The prognosis is poor, with almost 100% mortality within 3 years.
  • Transplant-associated KS:
    • Solid-organ transplant recipients receiving T-cell immunosuppression shows this variant
    • 100-fold greater risk than for immunocompetent patients.
    • Aggressive course
    • Lesions can regress as immunosuppression is reduced, but at the risk of organ rejection.
  • AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS:
    • It represents the most common HIV-related malignancy
    • Occurs in HIV-infected individuals 300-fold more commonly than in transplant recipients and 1000-fold greater than in the general population.
  • Pathogenesis: Virtually all KS lesions are infected by HHV8. (Choice B)
  • In classic KS (and sometimes in other variants), the cutaneous Lesions progress through three stages: (choice D)
    1. Patches are red-purple macules.
    2. With time, lesions become larger, violaceous, raised plaques
    3. Eventually, lesions become nodular and more distinctly neoplastic.

Key Takeaways:

  • Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is caused by HHV-8.
  • Classic KS progresses from patches to plaques to nodules.
  • Endemic African KS occurs in HIV-negative individuals, often in children.
  • KS lesions spread proximally from distal lower extremities.
